Thousands of tourists flock to the attraction, but there is plenty of room. A fortress worth seeing

All tourists enter the fort through the Main Gate. Built in 1873 by the British, they are a century younger than the Dutch ones.  The old gate is located behind the bastion of the Sun. They bear the Dutch abbreviation VOC (Vereinigte Oostindische Compagnie), the East India Company of the United Provinces, and a shield with the company's symbols - two lions and a rooster and the date 1669. The rooster (Gallo), which gave the name to the fort and the city, was inherited from the Portuguese, because they began building the fort back in 1588, limiting themselves to a wall from the land, because The Sinhalese kingdoms of Kotte and Kandy did not have a fleet, and they could not be afraid of attacks from the sea. The walls from the land (the bastion of the Moon with a Clock tower and the bastion of the Sun) are more powerful than from the sea. The Dutch had already built walls from the sea since 1649, rightly reasoning that it was not so much the local population that should be feared as colonizers from Europe. Just like them. The fears were not unfounded, and the fort was captured by the British in 1796, taking advantage of the occupation of the Netherlands by the French in 1795. At the same time, the fort, which had been fortified for so long, did not fire a single shot. The bastion at the old gate is the oldest.  It was built by the Portuguese, but its name is Dutch - Zwart.  Those who know German can guess by the consonance that it is "black".  Previously, the remains of the 17th-century Dutch ship Avondster, which sank nearby, were nearby, but they were washed out to sea in the terrible summer of 2004. The fort's 15 bastions, by the way, withstood the impact of the deadliest tsunami in history, which claimed the lives of almost 300,000 people in coastal countries. This proves once again in hindsight the level of the Dutch school of fortification. South of Zwart stands the Ackersloot bastion, erected shortly before the British captured it in 1789 and named after the birthplace of Captain Coster, who captured Halle in 1640. The eastern wall ends with the Utrecht bastion, also named after the famous Dutch city, the birthplace of football player Marco van Basten and erotic star Sylvia Kristel ("Emmanuel") (joke). There is a lighthouse built in 1938 on the cape nearby. Previously, before the lighthouse, signalmen from the Flag Rock bastion warned ships about the danger of rocks. In case of fog, the signal was given by the Musketeers. They shot from the nearest Pigeon Island, which could be reached from the fort at low tide. The inhabitants of the Netherlands could not do without their favorite wind turbines.  They installed it on the Triton bastion on the eastern wall. This is done specifically in the direction of the prevailing wind direction. The blades of the windmill rotated the gears of a pump that lifted seawater up. The Dutch watered the streets with it. But for sewage, the Dutch used the energy of the tides. At high tide, the water entered the network, and at low tide, it washed the feces into the sea. The old system is still working, so swimming near the fort is not recommended.

Galle Dutch Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, stands as one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, seamlessly blending colonial history, cultural heritage, and modern sophistication. My recent visit to this architectural marvel was nothing short of spectacular, offering a unique experience of walking through centuries-old cobblestone streets while indulging in modern luxuries. A Walk Through History Originally built by the Portuguese in 1588 and later fortified by the Dutch in the 17th century, Galle Fort has withstood the test of time, including tsunamis, wars, and changing civilizations. As I stepped inside the fort, I could feel the echoes of its colonial past‚Äîmassive stone walls, ancient churches, and Dutch-style buildings standing resiliently against the backdrop of the Indian Ocean. One of the most fascinating aspects of Galle Fort is how history coexists with modernity. While some ruins tell tales of the past‚Äîlike the crumbling bastions and weathered old warehouses‚Äîmany colonial-era buildings have been beautifully restored and converted into boutique hotels, caf√©s, art galleries, and luxury shops. Modern Elegance Amidst Ruins Despite being a centuries-old structure, Galle Fort has evolved into a vibrant, upscale destination. The streets are lined with stylish caf√©s, high-end boutiques, chic restaurants, and boutique hotels, giving it a European-inspired coastal town vibe. It‚Äôs a rare sight where you find luxury brands, artisanal ice cream shops, and handcrafted jewelry stores sitting inside historic Dutch-era buildings! While it has become modernized and somewhat commercialized, it hasn‚Äôt lost its old-world charm. The fort still preserves its ancient ramparts, lighthouses, old trading posts, and stone-paved alleyways, making it a unique destination where the past meets the present. Must-Visit Spots in Galle Fort 1. Galle Lighthouse One of the most picturesque and Instagram-worthy spots in the fort, this 19th-century lighthouse offers breathtaking views of the Indian Ocean. It‚Äôs a perfect spot to catch a golden sunset or simply enjoy the sea breeze. 2. The Dutch Hospital Shopping Precinct A beautifully restored colonial-era hospital that has now been transformed into a modern shopping and dining hub. This area is perfect for those looking to enjoy fine dining, sip cocktails, or shop for unique souvenirs. 3. The Ramparts & Bastions Walking along the fort‚Äôs ancient walls is an experience in itself. These massive stone fortifications once protected the fort from invasions and now serve as a stunning viewpoint for both history lovers and photographers. Sunsets here are absolutely magical! 4. Historical Churches & Museums ‚Ä¢ Dutch Reformed Church (Groote Kerk): Built in 1755, this church is one of the oldest Protestant churches in Sri Lanka. ‚Ä¢ National Maritime Museum: Showcases artifacts from shipwrecks and colonial-era maritime history. ‚Ä¢ All Saints‚Äô Church: A gorgeous Anglican church with intricate architecture and serene surroundings. 5. Flag Rock & Sunset Point At the far end of the fort lies Flag Rock, an old Portuguese watchtower that has now become a popular cliff-jumping and sunset-viewing spot. Watching the waves crash against the rocks while the sun dips below the horizon is an unforgettable experience. 6. The Quirky Streets & Hidden Alleys One of the best things to do in Galle Fort is to simply wander through its narrow, maze-like streets, each filled with hidden gems‚Äîantique shops, quirky caf√©s, street art, and local handicrafts. The vibe here is laid-back yet lively, perfect for leisurely exploration. The Food Scene ‚Äì A Gastronomic Delight! Galle Fort has become a foodie‚Äôs paradise, offering everything from Sri Lankan seafood specialties to international fine dining. Some must-visit spots include: ‚Ä¢ Pedlar‚Äôs Inn Caf√© ‚Äì A cozy caf√© serving excellent Sri Lankan rice & curry, coffee, and fresh seafood. ‚Ä¢ A Minute by Tuk Tuk ‚Äì Located inside the Dutch Hospital, offering stunning ocean views with delicious seafood. ‚Ä¢ Isle of Gelato ‚Äì The best place to grab some natural, handcrafted gelato to cool off after a day of exploring. Final Thoughts ‚Äì Why Galle Fort is a Must-Visit! ‚≠ê A perfect mix of history, culture, and modern luxury ‚≠ê Breathtaking ocean views and stunning sunsets ‚≠ê Instagram-worthy colonial architecture and charming streets ‚≠ê A haven for foodies, shopaholics, and history lovers alike ‚≠ê A unique blend of ancient ruins and trendy lifestyle spots Whether you‚Äôre a history enthusiast, a photographer, a foodie, or just someone looking for a relaxing getaway, Galle Dutch Fort has something for everyone. The beginning of the fort‚Äôs history, which was built by the Portuguese, along with a Franciscan chapel (now mostly in ruins) inside the fort started  in 1541. 100 years later the Dutch, with a force of some 2,500 men under Koster, captured the fort from the Portuguese in 1640. They started building the fort as seen in its present form in the Dutch architectural style. Fortifications were added up to the early 18th century. The British took over the fort on 23 February 1796, one week after Colombo was captured. Sri Lanka remained a British colony formally from 1815 till it became an independent island nation in 1948. The importance of Galle also declined after the British developed Colombo as their capital and main port in the mid nineteenth century. Today the Sri Lankan government and many Dutch people who still own some of the properties inside the fort are looking at making this one of the modern wonders of the world!  This work is going on still very slowly, I guess there is not enough money yet to build up the Fort to this modern wonder. Maybe the next generation!?
